p:
Climate change is altering the Earth’s global land and ocean temperatures. A 1 °C increase in global mean surface temperature was observed during the last years of the 2010s, relative to the pre-industrial period
1 . As a consequence, temperature variability and extreme heat events have become more frequent in many parts of the world. For example, unusually hot weather was observed during the 2003 heatwave in Central Europe. Overall, >70,000 deaths were estimated to be attributable to these extreme conditions, with more than one-third of the deaths occurring in France, Italy and Spain
2 . Since then, population exposure to extreme heat has increased worldwide, resulting in an additional 220 million heatwave exposure events in 2018 compared with the average in the years 1986–2005
3 .
